title: Add revise_audio YAML configuration parsing to decode_yaml/request
description:
Extend YAML config structure:
- Add ReviseAudio struct to decode_yaml/request/model.go
- Support subcategories (boolean flags) for selected tools:
  * revise_audio:rvc:yes (voice conversion)
  * revise_audio:prosody_dsp:yes (DSP prosody matching)
- Support verse selection:
  * List of verse references (e.g., [MAT.1.5, MAT.1.10])
  * Or reference to change list file
- Follow existing pattern from other config sections (audio_proof, compare, etc.)
- Add validation in decode_yaml/depend.go

title: Generate revised HTML report for review (old vs new audio)
description:
HTML report generator for revised audio:
- Similar structure to existing audio_proof HTML reports
- Show: verse reference, original text, revised text (if changed)
- Audio playback: original version + revised version
- Highlight which words were replaced
- Show source of replacement (book.chapter.verse, actor ID)
- Include before/after waveform visualization (optional, nice-to-have)
- Make it easy to review changes and validate quality
- Output: standalone HTML file (like existing reports)

title: Web UI integration: support revise_audio job submission via controller/web
description:
Extend web interface for revise_audio:
- Add revise_audio section to job submission form
- Allow upload of revision list file (JSON)
- Allow inline verse/word specification
- Display status/progress for revise_audio jobs
- Download links for:
  * Revised chapter audio files
  * Revised HTML report
- Integration with existing web UI patterns
- User-friendly error messages
- Documentation/help text for non-technical users

title: Implement corpus search: find replacement words/phrases in existing recordings
description:
Search logic for finding replacement snippets:
- Input: list of words/phrases to find (from revision request)
- Search strategy (in priority order):
  1. Same Actor ID + exact text match
  2. Same Actor ID + normalized text match
  3. Same Person + exact text match
  4. Different speaker + exact text match
- Search scope (fallback order): whole corpus, same book, nearby verses
- Return: candidate snippets with metadata (Actor, Person, book, chapter, verse, word timestamps, quality scores)
- Leverage existing Word table with timestamps for exact word boundaries

comments.author: jrstear
comments.text:
Clarifications from discussion:

1. Text normalization: Infer from existing code (check how text is normalized elsewhere in codebase)

2. Input format: Assume html_report generation code will handle word/phrase identification. Will receive aligned text and audio. Long-term may have just timecodes + replacement audio.

3. Distance scoring: Closer is better. Use word-distance, verse-distance, and book-distance. Create a composite 'away-from' score.

4. Speaker matching: Start WITHOUT Actor/Person info. Focus on text matching + distance first. Actor/Person matching will be added later as optimization (makes VC/prosody easier).

5. Return format: By default return best candidate, but provide option to get full ranked list with scores (text match, distance, actor factors).

6. Matching: Start with exact text matching only. No fuzzy/phonetic matching for now (note for later). No manual search UI for now (interesting idea, note for later).

7. Database indexes: Don't add unless functionally needed. Treat schema as not-in-my-domain for now.

8. See #4 above.

9. See #2 above.

10. Context matching: Good idea. Multiple passes - find all candidates first, then secondary searches to rank them by matching context words.

11. Audio snippet extraction: Don't duplicate metadata. Check if reusable layer exists (cli_misc/chop_audio/ uses ffmpeg directly, utility/ffmpeg/ffmpeg.go has ChopOneSegment). Build reusable layer in revise_audio if needed, then refactor chop_audio to use it later.

12. No matches: Return list of candidates to user (book/chapter/verse/word info) for manual audio editing punch-list. Don't fail, just report candidates.

comments.author: jrstear
comments.text:
Implementation approach:

1. Text normalization: Use simple case-insensitive matching with trimmed whitespace for now. Found normalizeURoman in mms_align.go (lowercase + remove punctuation), but for exact matching we'll start simpler. Can refine later.

2. Audio snippet extraction: Found utility/ffmpeg/ffmpeg.go has ChopOneSegment(ctx, tempDir, inputFile, beginTS, endTS) - perfect reusable function. Will use this directly, no need to build new layer yet.

3. Database queries: Will use SelectWordsByBookChapter and SelectFAScriptTimestamps. Need to query Words table for text matching. Audio file path comes from Scripts.audio_file column.

4. Distance calculation: Will compute verse distance (absolute difference in verse_seq), book distance (0 if same book, 1+ if different), and word distance (position in verse). Composite score: closer = better.

5. Multi-pass search:
   - Pass 1: Find all exact text matches in Words table
   - Pass 2: Rank by distance (verse, book)
   - Pass 3: (Future) Check context words for better ranking

6. Return format: SnippetCandidate struct already defined. Will return best match by default, with option to return full ranked list.

comments.author: jrstear
comments.text:
Database schema findings:

- Words table has: word_id, script_id, word_seq, verse_num, ttype, word, uroman, word_begin_ts, word_end_ts, fa_score
- Scripts table has: script_id, book_id, chapter_num, verse_str, audio_file, script_begin_ts, script_end_ts
- SelectFAWordTimestamps() gets words with timestamps but no book/chapter filter
- Need custom query: JOIN words + scripts, filter by book/chapter, get word text + timestamps + audio_file
- Word timestamps are relative to chapter audio file (word_begin_ts, word_end_ts)

For phrase matching: Need to find consecutive words matching replacement text. Will query words, group by script_id, check for consecutive sequences.

comments.author: jrstear
comments.text:
Final clarifications:

1. Multi-word phrase matching: Prefer whole phrase in existing snippet if available, otherwise assemble from multiple sources (words from different locations).

2. Audio file paths: Relative to FCBH_DATASET_FILES environment variable. Will resolve using os.Getenv("FCBH_DATASET_FILES") + audio_file path.

3. Verse distance: Use verse_num (start verse for snippet). May need to parse verse_str for ranges like "6-10". Per-word timing exists but may need to be extracted on-demand for matched verses (not all verses, only ones with matches).

4. Book distance: Simple 0 (same book) vs 1 (different book) approach.

Implementation plan:
- Create corpus_search.go with FindReplacementSnippets() function
- Query words table with JOIN to scripts for text matching
- Handle single-word and multi-word phrase matching
- Calculate distance scores (verse_num, book, word position)
- Return ranked SnippetCandidate list
- Use utility/ffmpeg/ChopOneSegment for audio extraction (separate task)

comments.author: jrstear
comments.text:
Implementation complete:

- Created corpus_search.go with CorpusSearcher
- Implemented FindReplacementSnippets() with phrase and word matching
- Text normalization: case-insensitive, trimmed
- Distance calculation: composite score (book + chapter + verse)
- Ranking: prioritizes exact matches, nearby verses, lower distance
- Returns best match by default, or all candidates if returnAll=true
- Handles actor/person info from scripts table
- Resolves audio file paths relative to FCBH_DATASET_FILES

Ready for testing with html_report test case.

title: Testing and validation: end-to-end revise_audio workflow
description:
Comprehensive testing:
- Test with real datasets (minority languages)
- Validate voice conversion quality (same speaker, different speaker cases)
- Validate prosody matching (natural-sounding transitions)
- Test edge cases:
  * Multiple words in sequence
  * Overlapping revisions
  * Words not found in corpus
  * Same word, different contexts
- Performance testing (large chapters, many revisions)
- User acceptance testing with non-technical users
- Document known limitations and best practices
- Create test datasets for regression testing

title: Enhance audio_proof HTML report: add selection UI for words/verses to revise
description:
Modify HTML report to allow selection:
- Add checkboxes/selection UI for each verse/word discrepancy
- Allow selecting entire verses or individual words within verses
- Visual highlighting of selected items
- Button to 'Export Revision List' or 'Create Revision Job'
- Export format: JSON file with selected revisions:
  * Verse references
  * Word indices (if word-level)
  * Original text, expected text
- Store selections client-side (localStorage) for user convenience
- Non-technical friendly UI (clear labels, instructions)

title: Implement audio snippet extraction from chapter files
description:
Extract word/phrase audio snippets:
- Input: word-level timestamps from corpus search results
- Extract audio segments from chapter files using timestamps
- Handle word sequences (multiple words that form a phrase)
- Add padding/context (e.g., 0.1s before/after for natural boundaries)
- Output: audio snippets as temporary files (WAV format)
- Reuse existing audio file handling from input package

title: Implement change list file format and parsing
description:
Standardized format for revision requests:
- JSON format for revision list:
  * Dataset reference
  * List of revisions (verse/word references)
  * Optional: word mappings (original -> replacement)
- Support both:
  * File-based input (user uploads/specifies file)
  * Inline YAML specification
- Parser to convert to internal RevisionRequest structure
- Validation: ensure verse references are valid, words exist in corpus
- Integration with existing Script/Word table queries

title: Implement DSP-based prosody matching (F0, energy, timing)
description:
Prosody adjustment using DSP (Phase 1, simplest approach):
- Extract prosody features from context (surrounding verses in target chapter):
  * F0 (pitch) contour
  * Energy/loudness envelope  
  * Speaking rate/timing
- Adjust extracted snippet to match:
  * Pitch shifting to match F0 contour
  * Time-stretching to match speaking rate
  * Loudness normalization
- Use librosa or similar for audio manipulation
- Keep natural-sounding (avoid artifacts)
- This is the "boring but important DSP" mentioned in notes

title: Integrate revise_audio into controller workflow
description:
Add revise_audio processing to controller:
- Add ReviseAudio method to controller/controller.go
- Process revise_audio config section (similar to audio_proof, compare)
- Coordinate with existing modules:
  * Read from database (Script/Word tables)
  * Use input package for audio file access
  * Use output package for revised audio files
  * Generate HTML reports
- Handle job dependencies: requires audio_proof to have run first
- Error handling and logging
- Status reporting for long-running operations

title: Implement audio stitching: replace segments in chapter audio
description:
Seamless audio replacement:
- Input: original chapter audio + list of (start_ts, end_ts, replacement_audio)
- Replace segments with crossfading at boundaries
- Crossfade duration: ~50-100ms for natural transitions
- Maintain chapter timing (don't shift later verses)
- Handle overlapping replacements
- Output: revised chapter audio file
- Preserve original as backup
- Validate duration matches (within tolerance)

title: Research and select voice conversion & prosody matching tooling stack
description:
Research available options and make recommendations:
- Voice conversion: RVC (existing FCBH system) vs OpenVoice vs other
- Prosody matching: DSP-based (F0/energy) vs neural approaches
- Prioritize: easiest/working solution first, can upgrade later
- Document decision with rationale in revise_audio/ directory
- Consider Go integration vs Python module (similar to existing MMS pattern)

comments.author: jrstear
comments.text:
Research complete. Recommendations documented in revise_audio/TOOLING_RESEARCH.md

Key decisions:
- Voice Conversion: Use existing FCBH RVC system (HuBERT + X-Vector + HiFi-GAN)
- Prosody Matching: Start with DSP-based (librosa + pyworld), upgrade to neural later if needed
- Integration: Follow MMS adapter pattern (Go â†’ Python subprocess)

Rationale: Leverages existing proven codebase, fastest path to working solution, language-agnostic, can upgrade incrementally.

comments.author: jrstear
comments.text:
Updated research document to be more critical and honest about uncertainties. Key changes:

- Separated externally verified facts from FCBH codebase claims
- Acknowledged that 'proven on minority languages' is a claim, not verified
- Noted that recommendation is pragmatic (use what exists) rather than optimal (best possible)
- Added section on what we actually know vs. what's claimed
- Suggested validation/comparison testing in Phase 2

The recommendation stands (use FCBH RVC) but now with appropriate caveats about uncertainty.

title: Integrate voice conversion (Python module): RVC-based speaker matching
description:
Voice conversion integration:
- Create Python module for VC (similar to mms/ adapter pattern)
- Use existing FCBH RVC infrastructure as starting point
- Accept: source audio + target speaker embedding
- Return: converted audio (same speaker identity)
- Handle cases: same speaker (passthrough), different speaker (VC needed)
- Extract speaker embeddings from target verse context
- Document integration approach (Go -> Python via subprocess/stdin-stdout or other)

title: Create revise_audio directory structure and Go module foundation
description:
Set up basic structure:
- Create revise_audio/ package directory
- Define core data structures (RevisionRequest, SnippetCandidate, etc.)
- Set up integration points with db package (Script, Word tables)
- Create interfaces for VC and prosody modules
- Basic error handling and logging

comments.author: jrstear
comments.text:
Created revise_audio directory structure and Go module foundation:

- models.go: Core data structures (RevisionRequest, SnippetCandidate, etc.)
- revise_audio.go: Main module struct
- vc_adapter.go: Voice conversion interface and RVC adapter stub
- prosody_adapter.go: Prosody matching interface and DSP adapter stub
- python/voice_conversion.py: Python stub for RVC integration
- python/prosody_match.py: Python stub for prosody matching
- build_env.sh: Conda environment setup (supports M1 Mac and AWS EC2)
- README.md: Documentation

All files follow existing patterns from mms/ modules. Python scripts use JSON I/O via stdin/stdout. Environment variables: FCBH_REVISE_AUDIO_VC_PYTHON and FCBH_REVISE_AUDIO_PROSODY_PYTHON.

title: Audio Revision System: Verse-level find-and-replace with voice cloning and prosody matching
description:
Epic: Build complete audio revision system for FCBH workflow. Users identify verses/words needing correction from audio_proof HTML reports, system finds replacement snippets in corpus, applies voice conversion and prosody matching, outputs revised chapter audio files + review HTML report.

Workflow:
1. User runs audio_proof with html_report
2. User identifies verses/words to revise from HTML report
3. System searches corpus for replacement snippets (prioritizing same speaker)
4. Extracts audio snippets
5. Applies voice conversion if needed (different speaker)
6. Adjusts prosody to match context
7. Stitches into revised chapter audio
8. Generates HTML report for review

Phase 1: Manual experiments (build infrastructure)
Phase 2: YAML integration + web UI

comments.author: jrstear
comments.text:
Phase 1 Dependency Flow:
1. arti-c12 (Research tooling) - First step
2. arti-wug (Directory structure) - Depends on research
3. arti-44l (Corpus search) - Depends on structure
4. arti-7qf (Snippet extraction) - Depends on search
5. arti-lmh (Voice conversion) - Depends on research + structure (can parallel with 44l)
6. arti-a2g (Prosody matching) - Depends on extraction + VC
7. arti-bue (Audio stitching) - Depends on prosody
8. arti-zh7 (CLI tool) - Depends on stitching
9. arti-1r4 (HTML report) - Depends on stitching

Phase 2 (YAML integration):
- Depends on Phase 1 completion
- arti-1j9, arti-6dt, arti-9j0 can proceed in parallel
- arti-b0j depends on YAML parsing + change list
- arti-3ky depends on controller integration
- arti-62u is final validation step

title: Create manual CLI tool for testing audio revision workflow
description:
Command-line tool for Phase 1 testing:
- Accept: dataset name, verse references, words to replace
- Example: ./revise_audio --dataset Test1 --verse MAT.1.5 --words "love" --target-actor 1
- Run full pipeline: search -> extract -> VC -> prosody -> stitch
- Output: revised chapter audio + metadata JSON
- Allow testing individual steps in isolation
- Useful for validating each component before YAML integration
